properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall or rain possible for Thursday night into Friday night. Precipitation will begin Thursday as flurries before potentially changing to rain during the day. There is uncertainty regarding the track of the low pressure system responsible for this precipitation, but total snowfall amounts of 10 to 15 cm or 15 to 25 mm of rain or a combination of the two are possible by Friday night. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-12T17:53:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T01:54:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2360909617.2020
Area: Agawa - Lake Superior Park, Chapleau - Missinaibi Lake, Gogama - Foleyet, Kirkland Lake - Englehart, Temiskaming Shores - Temagami
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall likely Thursday into Friday night. Snow, heavy at times, is expected to start Thursday and continue until Friday night before tapering to flurries on Saturday. There remains uncertainty regarding the track of the low pressure system responsible for the snow, but total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible by Friday night. Snowfall warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-12T17:52:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T01:53:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1400045189.2020
Area: Nakina - Aroland - Pagwa, Manitouwadge - Hornepayne, Kapuskasing - Hearst - Smooth Rock Falls, Timmins - Cochrane - Iroquois Falls
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, blowing snow and strong winds to end the week. An intense low pressure system will affect the whole province Friday and Saturday. An important snowfall will leave significant amounts of 15 to 25 centimetres of snow. Strong to high winds combined with snow will greatly reduce visibilities in blowing snow over the most exposed areas. The Quebec City area poses a challenge as localities north of the St. Lawrence may receive significant amounts of snow and ice pellets while also being affected by a more or less extended period of freezing rain. Areas south of the St. Lawrence River could be affected by some snow, freezing rain and even rain. As the exact track of the low remains uncertain, the type and amount of precipitation received could be significantly affected. Consider modifying any non-essential travel plans. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-12T17:44:43-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T01:45:43-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2097010089.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snow, and rain expected on Friday. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm for northernmost areas, 10 cm central areas, and 5 cm or less over southern areas. Total rainfall: 15 to 25 mm over southern areas, but locally higher amounts along the Fundy coast. Locations: New Brunswick. Time span: deteriorating conditions during the day Friday, and ending Friday night. Remarks: An intense disturbance will affect all of New Brunswick Friday, Snow is expected to begin Friday morning across the entire province. The snow will likely transition through freezing precipitation before changing to rain later in the day over southern portions of the province. Freezing precipitation could persist longer over central regions and extend over northeastern regions. Strong winds will also develop, with the highest gusts over coastal areas. Conditions will improve Friday night into Saturday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NBstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NBStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-12T19:17:09-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T03:18:09-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2501093526.2020

properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter storm likely Thursday night to Friday night. Light snow is expected to develop Thursday and become heavier early Friday morning. The heavy snow will continue until Friday night before tapering to flurries on Saturday. Strong gusty winds up to 70 km/h will accompany this storm causing blowing snow and low visibilities on Friday. Snowfall amounts could exceed 25 cm in some regions. ### Rapidly accumulating snow could make travel difficult over some locations. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-12T17:43:44-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T01:44:44-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2586925675.2020
Area: Fraserdale - Pledger Lake, Little Abitibi - Kesagami Lake
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A widespread and strong winter storm is expected to affect a number of western Arctic coastal communities beginning on Friday. Hazardous winter weather conditions are forecast to persist until Sunday night. Strong southerly winds are expected ahead of the system and may produce blizzard conditions in some areas Friday into Saturday. As the low pressure system moves eastward on Saturday, winds will shift to blow strongly from the northwest. These strong winds combined with fresh snow are expected to produce widespread blizzard conditions Saturday night and Sunday. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NTStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-12T20:17:07-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T04:18:07-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3598514379.2020
Area: Sachs Harbour, Paulatuk, Tuktoyaktuk - East Channel Region
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Winter Storm Watch In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Hazardous winter weather conditions are expected over parts of southern Alberta starting Thursday evening. Reduced visibility in blowing snow and heavy falling snow is expected to last through Saturday for some areas. There is some uncertainty as to how far south this storm system will develop; certainty will increase as the event draws nearer and this watch may be upgraded to warnings for some regions. Unseasonably cold temperatures will settle in over the province beginning Friday. Temperatures are expected to remain much colder than normal until early next week. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility in some locations. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ABstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ABStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-12T19:57:29-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T03:58:29-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1652986241.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Potential significant snowfall expected tonight through Thursday night. Snow, heavy at times, is forecast to begin tonight over Nipigon - Marathon - Superior north. Snowfall amounts up to 10 cm are expected. This snow is expected to ease in intensity Thursday morning or even transition to a few showers as temperatures warm to just above the freezing mark. By Thursday afternoon, any liquid precipitation is expected to transition back to heavy snow over Wawa - White River - Pukaskwa area. The heavy snow will then continue into Thursday night before coming to an end by Friday morning. Total snowfall amounts of 10 to 20 cm are possible by Friday morning. There remains uncertainty regarding the track of the low pressure system responsible for the snow. If heavier snowfall amounts appear likely Thursday, Snowfall Warnings may be required. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-12T17:42:48-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T01:43:48-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1005120429.2020
Area: Nipigon - Rossport, Marathon - Schreiber, White River - Dubreuilville, Wawa - Pukaskwa Park
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme wind chill values near minus 55 are expected to develop tonight and moderate on Thursday. ### Watch for cold related symptoms: shortness of breath, chest pain, muscle pain and weakness, numbness and colour change in fingers and toes. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-12T20:02:22-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T04:03:22-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2862027749.2020
Area: Gjoa Haven
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h. Locations: Hopedale and vicinity. Time span: Thursday morning until near midnight Thursday night. Remarks: Fresh snowfall will combine with strengthening northwesterly winds on Thursday to produce poor visibility in blowing snow. The snow will taper off near midnight Thursday night and winds will ease Friday morning. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Blowing snow advisories are issued when winds are expected to create blowing snow giving poor visibility to 800 metres or less for at least 3 hours. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-12T17:01:04-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T01:02:04-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3200245468.2020
Area: Hopedale and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, freezing precipitation and strong winds to end the week. An intense low pressure system will affect the whole province Friday and Saturday. Areas south of a line stretching from Central Abitibi toward the Beauce area could receive 15 to 30 millimetres of rain. Overnight Thursday to Friday and Friday morning, localities of the North Shore between Lachute and Trois-Rivières could be affected by a more or less extended period of freezing rain. Southerly winds should be especially strong over the Richelieu Valley and the St. Lawrence Valley Friday. The combination of the rain and mild temperatures will accelerate the melt of the snow cover. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.
Expires: 2020-03-12T17:44:06-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T01:45:06-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3346047739.2020

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow and blowing snow expected Thursday and Thursday night. Total snowfall: 5 to 15 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h. Locations: from Natuashish to Rigolet and vicinity. Time span: Thursday into Friday morning. Remarks: Snow, and strong northwesterly winds, are expected to develop in the Natuashish area Thursday morning and spread southward along the coast to Makkovik and Rigolet Thursday night. Fresh snowfall combined with strong winds will combine to reduce visibilities in blowing snow. A blowing snow advisory has been issued for Hopedale and vicinity. The public is advised to monitor future forecasts as warnings or advisories may be issued. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-03-12T17:01:56-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-03-12T01:02:56-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4154180079.2020
Area: Rigolet and vicinity, Postville - Makkovik, Nain and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada
